name: murrell
message: add R_eval_with_gd() to "lock" a graphics device during eval() calls during device drawing.  When graphics device is locked, any attempt to close/kill the device is ignored.  This is to protect against the user closing the device via asyncronous event (e.g., mouse click) during device drawing (which could result in a crash as killing the device left dangling device pointers for any drawing code that was still to complete)

name: murrell
message: Initial commit of R-groups branch.  This is a decent size because what began as a simple experiment (composition operators), working in R-devel, expanded to include multiple unforseen expansions (reusable groups and device transforms).  On the plus side, this initial commit contains what I think is a stable user API:  grid.group(src, op, dst);  grid.define(src, op, dst);  grid.use(group)

name: murrell
message: add 'engineDL' argument to set.gpar() to determine whether the call gets recorded on the graphics engine display list AND set engineDL=FALSE when calling set.gpar() from pushvpgp() in preDraw();  this is to correct behaviour of grobCoords(), which was polluting the graphics engine display list, which pollutes recorded plots;  it also affects drawGrob() and forceGrob(), but that is just fixing a problem that was previously hidden;  the thinking is this:  preDraw() does not need to record the set.gpar() on the display list because, in the case of drawGrob() the whole grob drawing is recorded on the display list (via recordGraphics()), and in the case of forceGrob() the preDraw() is just setting context for makeContent(), and in the case of grobCoords() the preDraw() is also just setting context for calculating coordinates (so in the latter two cases we do not want or need the set up for calculations recorded on the graphics engine display list);  on the other hand, when set.gpar() is called during pushViewport(), we DO want that on the engine display list because the whole pushViewport() process gets recorded on the engine display list as a series of separate calls into C code.

message: Make applyClosure call into execClosure to prevent future code drift.

name: kalibera
message: Performance optimization in applyClosure. The special context for argument matching is no longer needed.

name: kalibera
message: Fix error expression for primitives with internal argument matching (currently none is provided via matchArgs). This makes matchArgs consistent on error expressions and allows further optimization of applyClosure.

name: kalibera
message: Performance optimization in applyClosure. Actuals are implicitly protected via newrho and internally by NewEnvironment.

name: kalibera
message: Performance optimization in applyClosure. Variable newrho is not changed between setjmp and longjmp, and hence does not have to be volatile.

name: kalibera
message: Performance optimization in applyClosure. The return value is now stored in context and implicitly protected, hence the explicit protection and the local variable can be removed.

name: kalibera
message: Fix debugging prompt/srcref for functions that have body without braces. This fix also removes no longer needed code that updated R_Srcref in applyClosure debugging support - now R_Srcref is maintained even when not entering debugger.

name: kalibera
message: Fix srcref handling for S4 methods that have a body without braces. This fix synchronizes execClosure srcref handling with applyClosure.

name: kalibera
message: Performance optimization in applyClosure. R_Srcref is automatically saved into context by begincontext and is implicitly protected.

name: kalibera
message: Prevent unnecessary compilation of functions at serialization time with R_COMPILE_PKGS=1. Now R_COMPILE_PKGS has no direct impact on R, but it still advises INSTALL to enable/disable package compilation when needed. Compilation of base packages is now done using _R_COMPILE_PKGS_.

name: kalibera
message: Allow package compilation to be disabled by R_COMPILE_PKGS=0.

name: luke
message: Updated compiler to compile calls to non-syntactically-special base functions at optimization level 2, the default, as for level 3 but with a guard instruction.

name: luke
message: Added BASEGUARD instruction to place before inlined code for a call that assumes the called function is from base. If the guard fails, then the call is executed by the AST interpreter and the inlined code is skipped.

message: Fix for byte-compilation of packages (bypass code cache and strategies from serialization).

message: The following are half the files changed to compile R with C++. These are the simple, safe changes that keep the stricter compiler happy.

name: duncan
message: The while condition in find_recover_state looks like it should be *err, not just err == REG_NOERROR. Modernize K&R parameter definitions.  Explicit casting for calloc() return and enum values returned as int.

name: duncan
message: For the most part, these are simple updates to use modern parameter declarations rather than K&R.  The goal of all of the changes is to facilitate compiling R with C++ so that we can do more detailed diagnostic code analysis via the GCC translation unit dumps and also so that we can experiment with making R extensible by implementing it via C++.

name: duncan
message: Remove the R_INLINE if in C++ since the routine is referenced in a macro in bzlib_private.h and so in decompress.c.  gcc handles this, but g++ does not and that is sensible.  If we really want this to be inlined, then we should put it in the bzlib_private.h file

name: duncan
message: Additions to the parser for string literals, e.g 1L, 1e3L, 0x10L to create INTSXPs rather than REALSXPs.  Also, avoids some of the unnecessary creation of objects in the parser in the first pass when GenerateCode is false.  Feel free to make the warnings about constants such as 1.L and 1e-3L into syntax errors. For now, this is trying to be permissive.

name: duncan
message: Avoid coercing an INTSXP operand to a REALSXP in arithmetic when other operand is a REALSXP and so avoid making and having extra copy. Significant for very big vector. In some circumstances we see a speed up of a factor of 2. But there are lots of issues with GC, cache, vsize/nsize command line arguments which make getting good performance benchmarks difficult.  Running on base-Ex.r, etc. we see at least no decrease in performance!

name: duncan
message: Support in useDynLib() for a prefix and postfix via the .fixes argument.  Reorganization of the computations for mapping native symbols in name space so more of it happens when the NAMESPACE file is parsed, i.e. at installation. And changed several of the base packages to use this registration approach. stats still has some of the original name/PACKAGE.  This allows us to test both mechanisms.  stats also uses the prefix.  Will add documentation for new functions in base later or move them into the parseNamespace() function.  If we use the .registration in grDevices, we get a warning on Windows about savePlot being an existing R variable. This is legitimate, so we explicitly enumerate the symbols. We will have to add an .omit argument to useDynLib() or use a different prefix or explicitly map all symbols. Or we can use additional useDynLib directives in the conditional statements.

name: duncan
message: Check if symbol is NULL or its C routine info pointer

name: duncan
message: Workaround for PR#8450, the use of a cached rotine pointer when there is registration information available which is then ignored on all but the first call to that routine. For now, we just don't cache a routine if it has registration information.  This affects Windows.  And as people use the getNativeSymbolInfo() via the useDynLib() approach, this will go away entirely

name: duncan
message: The lookup of symbols in DLLs is now more centralized in a routine that is called by do_dotCode, do_dotcall and do_External. This routine combines the name and PACKAGE argument to find the symbol and can handle i) no PACKAGE argument when the function that called the native interface is within a namespace ii) when the symbol is a NativeSymbolInfo or "native symbol" external pointer iii) the PACKAGE is a DLLInfoReference object

name: hornik
message: New version of .find.package(). Use a null package argument to indicate all currently attached packages, so that functions like data() et al can use NULL as the default value for their package argument, rather the internal .packages(). Non-attached versioned package installs are now found (and hence also by system.file()), using the same selection logic as in library(). Add some sanity checking using DESCRIPTION package metadata. In library.dynam(), use NULL rather than .packages() as the package default value.

name: duncan
message: Fix for the problem reported by Roger Peng about seemingly random nesting of readline input warnings. This just puts a local signal handler before the call to R_waitForActivity(). This pops the readline stack if called and then calls the regular interrupt handler. We may want to make it easier to add routines that get called at the end of a context. Rather than having to nest these calls. I need to look closer and see what we have and whether we need a linked list of them.

name: duncan
message: Added a new signal which passes the newly available line as an argument to the callback. Made gtk_console_write understand a string length of -1. Swapped the references to the entries in the class when declaring the char and line signals. They seemed backward. But it really doesn't look like we are using them. This now works nicely with bindings for the GtkConsole class to allow us program things from R directly. Will make these bindings available soon as part of a package. (But you can generate them yourself using RGtkBindingGenerator).  Should work with gtk 2.0 sinc gtk_marshal_NON__STRING is defined there.

name: duncan
message: Allow the caller to pass a value of -1 to indicate that the routine should compute the length of the string itself. The string must be null terminated. This interface makes it consistent with Gtk widgets (and easier to generate programmatic bindings)

Configure is now created using Autoconf 2.50 or better: caching off by default, configure variables are precious; configure arg '--with-g77' and var 'FC' are deprecated in favor of var 'F77'.  'LDFLAGS' is used instead of 'LIBS' for '-L' flags for the linker. Document configure vars 'TCLTK_LIBS' and 'TCLTK_CPPFLAGS'. HPUX f90 works but needs the path to its static 'libF90.a' specified using 'LDFLAGS'.

name: duncan
message: The modules now explicitly register their function pointers rather than have the centralized loader resolve the symbols dynamically by looking in the shared library. This was motivated by the failure on the Dec T Tru64 reported by Brad McNeney. However, it is just a good thing to do as it reduces the dependency on the operating systems linker and dynamic loader and is more in keeping with the registration of native routines introduced recently. Tested on RH, YDL, Solaris. Needs checking on the Mac and Windows. Also needs to be verified on a machine without X11

Rdynpriv.h is for the internal, platform-specific interface for dynamic loading. Works on Linux, Windows. Not yet on Mac

name: duncan
message: Separate main() for Unix into initialization and mainloop() so that we can call the initialization from another application that links/loads R as a shared library. The change to errors.c allows such applications to override the default error handling in R to avoid the longjmp back to the top of the event loop. See the notes in embedded.html on the developer's site.  Work is needed on the makefile to recompile all the .o's with the correct flags (i.e an R_EMBEDDED and specifically the PIC option). The routines needed by applications are not in header files as we have to decide where to put these.

name: luke
message: Modified the name assignment loop in NewEnvironment to allow the namelist argument to be shorter than valualist.  In particular, namelist can be R_NilValue.  The remaining valuelist entries should already be named.  This allows NewEnvironment to be used to make environments from lists that already have names instead of building up the ENVSXP by hand.

name: duncan
message: Added the function commandArgs() as an .Internal like R.Version. Copies the command line arguments before they are processed so that we get them as they are passed in. These are used in the CORBA library and have other obvious uses, especially for running in non-interactive mode. This is done early in the process before the windows code can process away the name=value pairs.

name: duncan
message: The resulting R script in $R_HOME/bin/ now uses a current environment value for the variable R_HOME.  If this is not set, it uses the root of the current installation.  This is done via sed-substitution in the Makefile (.in) and relies on not using -R_HOME_DIR anywhere else in the R.sh.in script that doesn't want to be expanded in this way (i.e. as `pwd`).

message: A number of low-level changes to fix bugs.  1) as.real() etc now always try to use 7 significant digits rather than the value in options(); 2) duplicate() no longer forces promises, but rather copies the promise into the result.  This avoids some over-evaluation problems. Assignment to subsets now works properly, but the fix looks fragile. We may need a major redesign.
